results.title: End of the Road
results.creator_credit: Christina Crowley and O D N Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Acquaintance Rape”.
This film dramatises the occurrence of sexual assault between teenage acquaintances through an episode involving a teenage girl, who accepts a ride offered by an acquaintance after her car breaks down. This film points out various factors which contribute to the driver’s sexual assault, and emphasises the need for young people to understand their own sexual values and those of others. Written by Nancy Graham and Christina Crowley

results.title: Encore! : the best of Joan Sutherland
results.brief_description: Dame Joan Sutherland, Australian icon and declared National Treasure, has been described as the foremost soprano of our age and one of the greatest artists of all time. Live from the Sydney Opera House, performed by the Elizabethan Sydney Orchestra and conducted by Richard Bongyne, this video contains highlights of her stage performances with Opera Australia, including many of her most internationally famous and highly acclaimed roles.

results.title: Enchanted isles
results.creator_credit: Anglo-Scottish Pictures and Films of Scotland Committee
results.brief_description: A tour of the Hebrides, starting from Oban and crossing the water to Iona, St Columba’s Isle, and to Staffa and Fingal’s cave. The birthplace of Flora MacDonald and memories of Bonnie Prince Charlie. Also shows the industry and agriculture of the islands, including the weaving of Harris tweed.

results.title: Empty Land-New Life
results.brief_description: In 1956 the Ministry for Housing implemented the “Elderly Persons Housing Project” in an attempt to meet the growing demands for public housing by senior citizens. Over the years building costs have increased rapidly and the Ministry feels that if the Community were to donate land for the project this will enable them to continue building suitable accommodation at affordable prices.

results.title: Empowering people (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This instructional video uncovers the secrets of how to get people motivated to take more initiative, be more responsible, and reach their potential. Four main steps are recommended. One: empower yourself. This step is directed as managers/supervisors/team leaders; if managers behave like victims, externalising all their problems (i.e. blaming everyone and everything else) then staff will follow suit. Two: Demonstrate empowerment. For managers this means to accept responsibility for problems and go about fixing them your self. Three: give management guarantees that you (i.e. the employee) will implement suggestions. Four: take risks; directed at managers, the recommendation is to listen to and pilot staff ideas, not trounce on them, otherwise managers will be stymieing employees’ creative thinking and potentially losing out on implementing new and successful ideas.

results.title: Empirical formula by micro-analysis
results.creator_credit: Jack Smith and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: Shows procedures necessary to determine the empirical formula of a substance. Amounts of carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen are determined by estimating the weight of CO2, H2O and NH3 produced by the unknown. Students are expected to record the data and use it to ascertain the formula. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Emotional and social development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human development: the first 2 1/2 years”.
Discusses Erikson’s eight stages of development looking at the first two stages of trust versus mistrust and autonomy versus shame and doubt as applying to infants. A newborn baby moves through a development process to become a social being. Focuses on critical periods in development such as stranger anxiety, attachment, separation anxiety and preparation-individuation.

results.title: Emotion
results.creator_credit: Robert Aller and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
What exactly are emotions, and why do they have the power to dictate our lives? The first part of this program discusses the question of whether there are emotional responses common to and recognisable by all cultures, or whether culture plays a significant role in how emotion is expressed. There seem to be three consideration when studying emotion: what your body does, what your mind does and what you have learnt to do, and the latter part of the program looks at anger and anxiety in particular and how these powerful emotions can be used or controlled with these three considerations in mind.
